ideology_summary: Strong atheist who views organized religion as a control mechanism, not genuine spirituality. Distinguishes between 'spirituality' (which could be real) and 'religion' (man-made control). Religion gives people an avenue to control others or feel superior. If there is a god, that's between you and god - no reason to discuss it with others. Religious belief is a bastardization of true spirituality.

blurb.hook: In a world where the shepherd holds all the answers, one sheep begins to wonder if the hand that feeds is also the hand that controls.
blurb.conflict: When the shepherd claims to speak for God and threatens eternal damnation for disbelief, a lone sheep dares to ask: why would an infinite god need our worship? Why would he delegate his word to men who hoard power?
blurb.stakes: The shepherd's authority crumbles as questions mount - but the wolf is real, and leaving the flock means facing it alone. Will the sheep find truth, or just another pen?

summary_chunks: The Shepherd's Lie is an allegorical tale about a wandering sheep who questions the shepherd's claims about God.
The shepherd demands worship, tithes, and blind faith - threatening hell for disbelief.
The sheep points out the contradictions: men wrote the book, not God; why would an infinite being need finite worship?
It observes that religious leaders are judgmental and power-hungry, the opposite of divine.
The sheep concludes that if God exists, he's not in the temple or the book - he's probably out there doing something more interesting than judging whether you sang the right song.
The true spiritual path lies in questioning everything, not in following any shepherd.
lesson: If there is a god, that's between you and god — there's no reason to discuss it with other people.
The temple does not seek truth. It seeks obedience.
The shepherd does not serve the sheep. The sheep serve the shepherd.
And the god — if there is one — probably has better things to do than worry about whether you sang the right song on the right day.
The true spiritual path is not found in a building or a book. It is found in the question itself: What is real? What matters? What is true?
Follow those questions like a river. They will take you further than any shepherd ever could.
subtitle: In which the traveler discovers that the ones who claim to speak for the divine are often the furthest from it.
